title: What is a universal basic income? // Paris Marx

json.text: Comrades, there seems to have been a lot of talk about a universal basic income in the
past year, but I still get the feeling a lot of people don't know what that is. Let’s
talk about it.
We seem to have reached a point where, as a society, we know the distribution of income
is far too unequal, and the idea of full employment belongs to another time.
In a world so technologically-advanced, where automation devours more jobs every year, there
simply isn’t enough work to go around. How do we respond to these problems? Part of the
solution should be a universal basic income.
The Basic Income Earth Network describes the basic income as "an income unconditionally
granted to all on an individual basis, without means test or work requirement.”
What that basically means is everyone in society is guaranteed a certain level of income from
the government, regardless of how much money they make, whether or not they work, or a
whole number of other factors.
The amount of the basic income is usually enough to pay for the necessities of life,
and is tied to the rate of inflation so that as things get more expensive, it can continue
to cover the basic living expenses.
Does that mean it will be an excuse for people not to work? Not necessarily. The great thing
about a basic income is that it gives workers more bargaining power when seeking work, so
if they’re without a job there’s no sense of urgency to find another. They have enough
money to get by, so they can spend more time trying to find a job that better fits their
skills and interests, and will pay them fairly.
Some people may choose to work less though. Let’s look at some examples. Right now a
lot of students work in order to pay for living expenses or school. With a basic income, they’d
be able to spend more time focused on their studies, and less time working.
A lot of countries have good parental leave schemes, but some parents like to spend more
time with their children while they're young, and a basic income would support them in doing
that.
Many artists never make enough from their art to make it their sole focus, but with
a basic income they’d be able to work less at side jobs, or not at all, depending on
how much their art earned them.
And as a final example, consider entrepreneurs. It can take a while for a new business venture
to show a profit, and a basic income would help small business owners get through those
tough early days.
A basic income not only gives the poor and middle-class more spending power, which fuels
the economy, but it has the opportunity to revolutionize work, by allowing more people
to work part-time.
This would have the dual result allowing more people to work, as we’d all be working fewer
hours on average, and it would give us more time to enjoy our lives, spend time with friends
and family, and do the things we enjoy.
One of the biggest critiques of a basic income comes from those saying it would cause a great
spike in inflation, but there’s actually little evidence to support that. Inflation
is caused by an increase in the money supply, or when the money supply increases at a greater
rate than the overall economy.
However, a basic income isn’t funded with new money. It doesn’t increase the money
supply, because it’s funded through redistribution. A basic income can save money on other social
programmes, or make some programmes or tax cuts completely irrelevant.
Considering the massive inequality we now have to deal with, and the damage too much
inequality does to our societies, a basic income should also be funded with higher taxes
on the rich and corporations, so the end result is a much more equal society.
A basic income would help us deal with so many of the problems we have in the world
today, but there’s another argument to be made for it. We only live once, so we should
try to make that life as good as possible for as many people as possible. That’s not
what we’re doing right now though. We’re letting a small elite live unthinkingly well,
while the rest of us suffer. It's time to change that, and a basic income will help
us to do it.
Comrades, if you think we should adopt a basic income, make sure to like this video and share
it with your friends. In the next video I’ll be talking about some real-world examples
of the basic income in practice, so make sure to subscribe for that. Thanks for watching.
For more than 20 years, the elites have been negotiating toward a two-state solution to
the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, but it seems further away now than ever.
